questions.text: A 36-year-old female was referred to our hospital with morbid obesity and T1DM. Although a temporary weight loss and reduction in daily insulin dose were achieved with an in-hospital treatment, her weight rebounded shortly after discharge. The patient experienced difficulty in controlling her body weight. The patient expressed her intention for surgical treatment for weight loss. Absolute contraindications for bariatric surgery include:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Contraindications for bariatric surgery include Prohibitive surgical risk, ASA IV, Reversible endocrine or other disorders that can cause obesity, Current drug or alcohol misuse, Uncontrolled, severe psychiatric illness, Uncontrolled, severe bulimia, Lack of comprehension of risks, benefits, expected outcomes, alternatives, and lifestyle change

Highyeild:

Bariatric Surgery: Bariatric surgery involves the manipulation of the stomach and/or small bowel to achieve weight loss and control of the obesity-related disease. The Rationale for Surgery : Because of the tendency for the basal metabolic rate to decrease with dieting, most people will regain all their weight, returning to the previous homeostatic set point Bariatric surgery appears to alter this mechanism and ‘reset’ this point[Bariatric surgery leads to a weight loss of 25–35% of body weight (usually at least 15 kg) after 1 year, and sustained weight loss maintenance at 15–25% after 20 years] Bariatric surgery leads to long-term survival benefits and improves obesity-related disease and quality of life Common Surgical Procedures: Sleeve Gastrectomy Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass One-anastomosis gastric bypass Gastric Binding Biliopancreatic Diversion/Duodenal Switch Single-anastomosis duodeno ileal bypass with sleeve gastrectomy Estimated early surgical complication rates, operative mortality after sleeve gastrectomy, Roux-en-Y or one- anastomosis gastric bypass, and gastric banding, and late complications. Early Mortality Late Sleeve gastrectomy Leak at angle of His (1-2%) 0.1% Gastro-oesophageal reflux Intra-abdominal bleed (2-3%) Barrett's oesophagus DVT/PE (<1%) Weight regain Gastric bypass Anastomotic leak (<1%) 0.1% Internal hernia Intra-abdominal bleed (2-3%) Chronic abdominal pain Unspecified obstruction (1-2%) Malnutrition if long limb bypass DVT/PE (<1%) Anastomotic ulcer/stricture Weight regain Gastric band Access port infection (1%) 0.05-0.1% Band infection DVT/PE (<0.1%) Tubing leak Slippage Erosion into stomach Band intolerance Failure to lose weight/weight regain

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Cardiomyopathy is not a contraindication for bariatric surgery. Option B. Pickwickian syndrome is not a contraindication for bariatric surgery. Option C. Type 1 diabetes mellitus is not a contraindication for bariatric surgery.

Extraedge:

Understanding that the obesity epidemic currently experienced in diferent parts of the world is driven by a change in the environment towards becoming ‘obesogenic’ and not a lack of willpower would be the first step in removing the barriers to more surgery. All surgeons should contribute their results to national registries so that safety can be monitored and operation trends established. Ideally registries should also link to other national healthcare records, e.g. diabetes databases, so that long-term outcomes data can be collected outside of funded RCTs

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with chest discomfort and was subsequently diagnosed with metabolic syndrome. Which of the following is not considered a part of metabolic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

End-stage renal disease Metabolic syndrome includes type 2 diabetes mellitus (insulin resistance), dyslipidaemia, and hypertension. Patients with this constellation of problems are obese, with central body obesity being the primary essential feature (waist circumference >35 inches in women or >40 inches in men). The syndrome is characterised by impaired hepatic uptake of insulin, systemic hyperinsulinemia, and tissue resistance to insulin. Patients with metabolic syndrome are at high risk for early cardiovascular death.

questions.text: A 26-year-old girl presented for her initial evaluation with bariatric surgery. Which of the following bariatric procedures is primarily intended to induce weight loss through the malabsorption of ingested nutrients?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duodenal switch Bariatric procedures are classified as restrictive, malabsorptive, or a combination of restrictive and malabsorptive in the weight loss mechanism that they induce. Malabsorptive operations include duodenal switch and biliopancreatic diversion . The weight loss mechanism by the duodenal switch is primarily based on malabsorption and was developed to help lessen the high incidence of marginal ulcers after Biliopancreatic diversion.

Highyeild:

BPD(Bil produces more significant weight loss than other procedures but is associated with a higher nutritional complication rate. The mechanism of action is mainly the malabsorption of calories . BPD/DS is the version mainly performed. Procedure: A sleeve gastrectomy is followed by a division of the duodenum distally to the pylorus. The ileum is divided with a linear stapler, followed by a duodenoileostomy and ileoileostomy to create a shared channel of 75–125 cm and an alimentary channel of 100–250 cm. The long remaining biliary limb is not measured. Post-Operative Care : BPD/DS is increasingly considered a definitive procedure, particularly after significant weight regains following sleeve gastrectomy. A high-protein diet and regular vitamin and mineral supplements, with lifelong monitoring and patient commitment to avoid malnutrition, are essential postoperatively.

Sleeve gastrectomy is a restrictive procedure that reduces food intake and affects the absorption of nutrients and the secretion of metabolic hormones. Option C. The mechanism of action Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) is a combination of restriction and malabsorption of calories.

questions.text: Early postoperative complications after a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass procedure include EXCEPT

options.label: A
options.text: Anastomotic leaks from a staple line

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperglycaemia Early postoperative complications after RYGB anastomotic leak from a staple line, gastric remnant dilation due to downstream obstruction, intra-abdominal bleeding, and pulmonary complications such as atelectasis and pulmonary embolus. Diabetes, if present, usually improves promptly after RYGB, and hyperglycemia is unlikely to be problematic.

Highyeild:

Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass Roux-en-Y gastric bypass should include a short vertical lesser curvature-based gastric pouch. Techniques: Linear stapler with suture closure of the defect Circular stapler Entirely hand sewn. The Roux limb can be retro- or ante-colic. There is no standard length for the biliary and Roux limbs; however, the biliary limb is usually kept short to reduce vitamin and mineral deficiencies, and the Roux limb length is varied between 100 and 150 cm. Bowel continuity is restored by a ‘Y’ jejunojejunostomy , which is either stapled with suture closure of the defect or stapled in its entirety. It is now recognised that the mechanism of action is complex. Supportive Care: Change in satiety gut hormones. Changes in energy expenditure Change in food preferences

questions.text: A 52- year-old woman underwent laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy for morbid obesity (BMI 35.1) and related morbidities. What is the most common intraoperative complication following a sleeve gastrectomy procedure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intra-abdominal bleed A sleeve gastrectomy operation is less challenging than a gastric bypass. The overall bleeding rate for the staple line after Sleeve Gastrectomy is generally cited as about 2%.

Highyeild:

Sleeve gastrectomy is less challenging to perform than gastric bypass. It evolved from the magenstrasse and mill operation, in which the divided fundus (the ‘mill’) was left in continuity with the lesser curve-based tube (the ‘main street’). The lesser curve-based gastric tube is constructed over a size 32–36 Fr bougie, although some surgeons advocate using larger sizes to reduce the risk of staple line leakage. Linear stapling devices are used. There is variation in the techniques employed between how wide the staplers should be and whether reinforcement strips should be used. The Achilles heel of the sleeve is the risk of a staple line leak at the angle of His, which can take months to heal owing to the high-pressure system in the stomach with an intact pylorus. Another concern in the long term is symptomatic reflux and, de novo, Barrett’s oesophagus. A change in satiety gut hormones and bile salt metabolism, similar to those described after gastric bypass, may explain some of the phenomena observed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. GERD is a late postoperative complication following sleeve gastrectomy. Option B. Pulmonary embolism constitutes about < 1% of early postoperative complications following sleeve gastrectomy. Option D. Deep vein thrombosis constitutes about < 1% of early postoperative complications following sleeve gastrectomy.

questions.correct_answer: C. A 48-year-old man with a BMI of 36 and a Family History of Diabetes Mellitus.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A 48-year-old man with a BMI of 36 and a Family History of Diabetes Mellitus. Only People with a BMI ≥35 WITH comorbidities are candidates for metabolic surgeries.

Highyeild:

The National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) in the UK recommends consideration of bariatric surgery for people with severe obesity in whom all non-surgical measures have been tried with no adequate weight loss achieved or maintained. 2014 updated NICE guidance on bariatric surgery Bariatric surgery is a treatment option for anyone with a BMI ≥40. Offer an expedited assessment for people with a BMI ≥35 with the onset of type 2 diabetes in the past 10 years. Consider an assessment for people with a BMI of 30–34.9 with the onset of type 2 diabetes within 10 years. Consider an assessment for people of Asian origin with the onset of type 2 diabetes at a lower BMI than other populations. Bariatric surgery is the option for adults with BMI >50 when other interventions are ineffective. People fitting the above criteria must also receive an assessment in a specialist weight-management service before referral to a surgical team.

questions.text: After a 44-year-old man underwent a successful Gastric Banding Procedure, he was advised additional medical supplementations. Which of the following are the required supplements? Thiamine. Vitamin D. Iron. Selenium, Copper, & Zinc. Vitamin B12. Vitamin A. Vitamin K. Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3 Thiamine is needed after gastric Banding. Vitamin D is needed after gastric Banding. Iron is needed after gastric Banding.

Highyeild:

Objective: ‘sweet spot’ of optimal appetite control. Advantages : Perioperative safety, Lack of nutritional complications Relative ease and availability. Procedure : The pars flaccida technique (through the window of the lesser omentum) is now standard practice with a band placed just below the oesophagogastric junction, making a small ‘virtual’ gastric pouch. The band is sutured into place anteriorly with gastro gastric tunnelling sutures to reduce slippage. The access port is routinely sutured to the rectus sheath in the upper abdomen for ease of access by a non-coring Huber needle for band adjustments. The operation works by reducing hunger, probably vagally mediated . Initial surgical placement is only the beginning of the treatment. Specialist nurses, physicians and surgeons do ‘band consultations’ to assess eating habits and then perform an adjustment with injection or aspiration of saline if indicated. Postoperative Care: Follow-up should be monthly during the first year, with full MDT support to help patients get the best use out of their bands.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with BMI 52, a known Diabetic with HbA1c 6%, was planned for Metabolic surgery. Which procedure is known to cause the highest percentage of diabetes remission after surgery?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biliopancreatic diversion/duodenal switch. Biliopancreatic diversion/duodenal switch produces 80% 3-year % diabetes remission. It produces more significant weight loss than other procedures but is associated with a higher nutritional complication rate.

Highyeild:

BPD(Bil produces more significant weight loss than other procedures but is associated with a higher nutritional complication rate. The mechanism of action is mainly the malabsorption of calories . BPD/DS is the version mainly performed. Procedure: A sleeve gastrectomy is followed by a division of the duodenum distally to the pylorus. The ileum is divided with a linear stapler, followed by a duodenoileostomy and ileoileostomy to create a common channel of 75–125 cm and an alimentary channel of 100–250 cm. The long remaining biliary limb is not measured. Post-Operative Care : BPD/DS is increasingly considered a definitive procedure, particularly after significant weight regains following sleeve gastrectomy. A high-protein diet and regular vitamin and mineral supplements with lifelong monitoring and patient commitment to avoid malnutrition are essential postoperatively.
